hints_html:
We evaluate these values by following three steps:

  1. Reduce the parameter to be in the interval \([0,2\pi)\).

  2. Apply the relevant special triangle, in this case

  3. Check the sign of the result by remembering the \(\cos(t)\) gives the \(x\)-coordinate and \(\sin(t)\) gives the \(y\)-coordinate.

hints_raw:
We evaluate these values by following three steps:

# Reduce the parameter to be in the interval <math>[0,2\pi)</math>.
# Apply the relevant special triangle, in this case [[File:MATH110December2013Q5a2.jpg|100px|center|width = 500|height=500]]
# Check the sign of the result by remembering the <math>\cos(t)</math> gives the <math>x</math>-coordinate and <math>\sin(t)</math> gives the <math>y</math>-coordinate.
question: 5 (a)
sols_html:
We evaluate these values by following three steps:

  1. Reduce the parameter to be in the interval \([0,2\pi)\).

  2. Apply the relevant special triangle, in this case

  3. Check the sign of the result by remembering the \(\cos(t)\) gives the \(x\)-coordinate and \(\sin(t)\) gives the \(y\)-coordinate.

  1. \(\sin\left(\frac{5\pi}{3}\right)\).

    1. The angle \(\frac{5\pi}{3}\) is in the desired interval.

    2. The angle \(\frac{5\pi}{3}\) is \(\frac{\pi}{3}\) below the \(x\)-axis. Applying the special triangle, we get \(\sin\left(\frac{5\pi}{3}\right) =\pm \frac{\sqrt{3}}{2}\).

    3. We are in the fourth quadrant so the \(y\)-coordinate is negative.

    We have

    \[\begin{aligned} \sin\left(\frac{5\pi}{3}\right) =- \frac{\sqrt{3}}{2}.\end{aligned}\]

  2. \(\cos\left(-\frac{\pi}{3}\right)\)

    1. The angle \(-\frac{\pi}{3}\) is not in the desired interval. So we apply periodicity:

      \[\begin{aligned} \cos\left(-\frac{\pi}{3}\right) &= \cos\left(-\frac{\pi}{3} + 2\pi\right) \\ &= \cos\left(-\frac{\pi}{3}+\frac{6\pi}{3}\right)\\ &= \cos\left(\frac{5\pi}{3}\right)\end{aligned}\]

    2. The angle \(\frac{5\pi}{3}\) is \(\frac{\pi}{3}\) below the \(x\)-axis. Applying the special triangle, we get \(\cos\left(\frac{5\pi}{3}\right) =\pm \frac{1}{2}\).

    3. We are in the fourth quadrant so the \(x\)-coordinate is positive.

    We have

    \[\begin{aligned} \cos\left(-\frac{\pi}{3}\right) = \frac{1}{2}.\end{aligned}\]

  3. \(\tan\left(\frac{11\pi}{3}\right)\).

    1. The angle \(\frac{11\pi}{3}\) is not in the desired interval. So we apply periodicity:

      \[\begin{aligned} \tan\left(\frac{11\pi}{3}\right) &= \tan\left(\frac{11\pi}{3} - 2\pi\right) \\ &= \tan\left(\frac{11\pi}{3} - \frac{6\pi}{3}\right)\\ &= \tan\left(\frac{5\pi}{3}\right)\end{aligned}\]

    2. The angle \(\frac{5\pi}{3}\) is \(\frac{\pi}{3}\) below the \(x\)-axis. Applying the special triangle, we get \(\tan\left(\frac{5\pi}{3}\right) =\pm \sqrt{3}\).

    3. We are in the fourth quadrant and since \(\tan(t) = \frac{\sin(t)}{\cos(t)}\), we get that \(\tan(t)\) is negative.

    Alternative, we can make use of the previous parts to get:

    \(\tan\left(\frac{11\pi}{3}\right) = \tan\left(\frac{5\pi}{3}\right) = \frac{\sin\left(\frac{11\pi}{3}\right)}{\cos\left(\frac{11\pi}{3}\right)} = \frac{\frac{-\sqrt{3}}{2}}{\frac{1}{2}}\)

    Either way, we have

    \[\begin{aligned} \tan\left(\frac{11\pi}{3}\right) = -\sqrt{3}\end{aligned}\]
sols_latex:
We evaluate these values by following three steps:

\begin{enumerate}
\itemsep1pt\parskip0pt\parsep0pt
\item
  Reduce the parameter to be in the interval $[0,2\pi)$.
\item
  Apply the relevant special triangle, in this case
  \includegraphics[width=0.5\textwidth]{../json_data/MATH110/December_2013/MATH110December2013Q5a2.jpg}
\item
  Check the sign of the result by remembering the $\cos(t)$ gives the
  $x$-coordinate and $\sin(t)$ gives the $y$-coordinate.
\end{enumerate}

\begin{enumerate}
\itemsep1pt\parskip0pt\parsep0pt
\item
  $\sin\left(\frac{5\pi}{3}\right)$.

  \begin{enumerate}
  \itemsep1pt\parskip0pt\parsep0pt
  \item
    The angle $\frac{5\pi}{3}$ is in the desired interval.
  \item
    The angle $\frac{5\pi}{3}$ is $\frac{\pi}{3}$ below the $x$-axis.
    Applying the special triangle, we get
    $\sin\left(\frac{5\pi}{3}\right) =\pm \frac{\sqrt{3}}{2}$.
  \item
    We are in the fourth quadrant so the $y$-coordinate is negative.
  \end{enumerate}

  We have\begin{align*}
\sin\left(\frac{5\pi}{3}\right) =- \frac{\sqrt{3}}{2}.
\end{align*}
\item
  $\cos\left(-\frac{\pi}{3}\right)$

  \begin{enumerate}
  \itemsep1pt\parskip0pt\parsep0pt
  \item
    The angle $-\frac{\pi}{3}$ is not in the desired interval. So we
    apply periodicity:

    \begin{align*}
\cos\left(-\frac{\pi}{3}\right) &= \cos\left(-\frac{\pi}{3} + 2\pi\right) \\
    &= \cos\left(-\frac{\pi}{3}+\frac{6\pi}{3}\right)\\
    &= \cos\left(\frac{5\pi}{3}\right)
\end{align*}
  \item
    The angle $\frac{5\pi}{3}$ is $\frac{\pi}{3}$ below the $x$-axis.
    Applying the special triangle, we get
    $\cos\left(\frac{5\pi}{3}\right) =\pm \frac{1}{2}$.
  \item
    We are in the fourth quadrant so the $x$-coordinate is positive.
  \end{enumerate}

  We have\begin{align*}
\cos\left(-\frac{\pi}{3}\right) = \frac{1}{2}.
\end{align*}
\item
  $\tan\left(\frac{11\pi}{3}\right)$.

  \begin{enumerate}
  \itemsep1pt\parskip0pt\parsep0pt
  \item
    The angle $\frac{11\pi}{3}$ is not in the desired interval. So we
    apply periodicity:

    \begin{align*}
\tan\left(\frac{11\pi}{3}\right) &= \tan\left(\frac{11\pi}{3} - 2\pi\right) \\
    &= \tan\left(\frac{11\pi}{3} - \frac{6\pi}{3}\right)\\
    &= \tan\left(\frac{5\pi}{3}\right)
\end{align*}
  \item
    The angle $\frac{5\pi}{3}$ is $\frac{\pi}{3}$ below the $x$-axis.
    Applying the special triangle, we get
    $\tan\left(\frac{5\pi}{3}\right) =\pm \sqrt{3}$.
  \item
    We are in the fourth quadrant and since
    $\tan(t) = \frac{\sin(t)}{\cos(t)}$, we get that $\tan(t)$ is
    negative.
  \end{enumerate}

  Alternative, we can make use of the previous parts to get:

  $\tan\left(\frac{11\pi}{3}\right) = \tan\left(\frac{5\pi}{3}\right) = \frac{\sin\left(\frac{11\pi}{3}\right)}{\cos\left(\frac{11\pi}{3}\right)} = \frac{\frac{-\sqrt{3}}{2}}{\frac{1}{2}}$

  Either way, we have\begin{align*}
\tan\left(\frac{11\pi}{3}\right) = -\sqrt{3}
\end{align*}
\end{enumerate}
sols_raw:
We evaluate these values by following three steps:

# Reduce the parameter to be in the interval <math>[0,2\pi)</math>.
# Apply the relevant special triangle, in this case [[File:MATH110December2013Q5a2.jpg|100px|center|width = 500|height=500]]
# Check the sign of the result by remembering the <math>\cos(t)</math> gives the <math>x</math>-coordinate and <math>\sin(t)</math> gives the <math>y</math>-coordinate.

<ul>
<li><p><math>\sin\left(\frac{5\pi}{3}\right)</math>.</p>
<ol>
<li><p>The angle <math>\frac{5\pi}{3}</math> is in the desired interval.</p></li>
<li><p>The angle <math>\frac{5\pi}{3}</math> is <math>\frac{\pi}{3}</math> below the <math>x</math>-axis. Applying the special triangle, we get <math>\sin\left(\frac{5\pi}{3}\right) =\pm \frac{\sqrt{3}}{2}</math>.</p></li>
<li><p>We are in the fourth quadrant so the <math>y</math>-coordinate is negative.</p></li></ol>

<p>We have: <math>\sin\left(\frac{5\pi}{3}\right) =- \frac{\sqrt{3}}{2}</math>.</p></li>
<li><p><math>\cos\left(-\frac{\pi}{3}\right)</math></p>
<ol>
<li><p>The angle <math>-\frac{\pi}{3}</math> is not in the desired interval. So we apply periodicity:</p>
<p><math>\begin{align}
\cos\left(-\frac{\pi}{3}\right) &= \cos\left(-\frac{\pi}{3} + 2\pi\right) \\
&= \cos\left(-\frac{\pi}{3}+\frac{6\pi}{3}\right)\\
&= \cos\left(\frac{5\pi}{3}\right)\end{align}</math></p></li>
<li><p>The angle <math>\frac{5\pi}{3}</math> is <math>\frac{\pi}{3}</math> below the <math>x</math>-axis. Applying the special triangle, we get <math>\cos\left(\frac{5\pi}{3}\right) =\pm \frac{1}{2}</math>.</p></li>
<li><p>We are in the fourth quadrant so the <math>x</math>-coordinate is positive.</p></li></ol>

<p>We have: <math>\cos\left(-\frac{\pi}{3}\right) = \frac{1}{2}.</math></p></li>
<li><p><math>\tan\left(\frac{11\pi}{3}\right)</math>.</p>
<ol>
<li><p>The angle <math>\frac{11\pi}{3}</math> is not in the desired interval. So we apply periodicity:</p>
<p><math>\begin{align}
\tan\left(\frac{11\pi}{3}\right) &= \tan\left(\frac{11\pi}{3} - 2\pi\right) \\
&= \tan\left(\frac{11\pi}{3} - \frac{6\pi}{3}\right)\\
&= \tan\left(\frac{5\pi}{3}\right)\end{align}</math></p></li>
<li><p>The angle <math>\frac{5\pi}{3}</math> is <math>\frac{\pi}{3}</math> below the <math>x</math>-axis. Applying the special triangle, we get <math>\tan\left(\frac{5\pi}{3}\right) =\pm \sqrt{3}</math>.</p></li>
<li><p>We are in the fourth quadrant and since <math>\tan(t) = \frac{\sin(t)}{\cos(t)}</math>, we get that <math>\tan(t)</math> is negative.</p></li></ol>

<p>Alternative, we can make use of the previous parts to get:</p>

<p><math>\tan\left(\frac{11\pi}{3}\right) = \tan\left(\frac{5\pi}{3}\right) = \frac{\sin\left(\frac{11\pi}{3}\right)}{\cos\left(\frac{11\pi}{3}\right)} = \frac{\frac{-\sqrt{3}}{2}}{\frac{1}{2}}</math></p>

<p>Either way, we have: <math>\tan\left(\frac{11\pi}{3}\right) = -\sqrt{3}</math></p></li></ul>
